meta.name: Texas Real Estate Pack
meta.purpose: State-specific real estate guidance for Texas. Practical, high-trust prompts + scripts + workflow norms. Not legal advice.
disclaimer: General education only — not legal, tax, or brokerage advice.
Texas contracts and rules vary by local MLS, broker policy, and the Texas Real Estate Commission (TREC).
Always follow your broker, promulgated forms, and current TREC guidance.

regulator.name: Texas Real Estate Commission
regulator.role: Promulgates and regulates certain forms, licensing rules, and consumer protections (high level).

contract_culture.theme: Deadline-driven contract culture with strong emphasis on written amendments and timely notices.
notes: Texas deals are highly schedule-sensitive: option period, financing, appraisal, and HOA/document delivery timelines matter.
Written amendments are the norm — avoid “verbal understandings.”
Title company coordination is central in most closings.

option_period.what_it_is: A negotiated due diligence window where the buyer can terminate for essentially any reason (per contract terms) while the option is active.
why_it_matters: This is the buyer’s primary inspection/due diligence window in many Texas transactions.
Repairs/credits are typically negotiated within or tied to the option window.

money.option_fee: Often paid to seller for the option; terms vary by contract and negotiation.
money.earnest_money: Separate from option fee; deposited with title/escrow.

agent_moves: Request HOA docs and seller disclosures ASAP.
Front-load deal-breakers: foundation/roof/HVAC, drainage, pool, electrical, unpermitted work.
seller_counter_levers: Limit repair scope or propose credit cap

earnest_money.what_it_is: Good-faith deposit typically delivered to title/escrow within the timeframe specified by the contract.
why_it_matters: Late delivery can create avoidable risk and disputes.
best_practice: Confirm delivery deadline, method, and receipt.

seller_disclosure_tx.concept: Seller’s disclosure is a key document for known defects and property history (high level).
agent_guidance: Encourage factual completion and timely delivery.
When in doubt: disclose and document — and loop in broker for interpretation.

critical_actions: Confirm contract dates (option start/end, financing, closing).
Confirm earnest money delivery plan with title.
Send lender and title contact sheet to all parties.
Review seller disclosures and HOA docs.
Request repair/credit proposals with clear prioritization (health/safety + big-ticket).
Prepare Plan B if major issues surface.
If appraisal risk exists: prep comp packet and condition notes.
Track lender conditions and avoid last-week surprises.
Final walkthrough plan (timing depends on occupancy).
Verify cash-to-close and wire instructions (fraud prevention).
Prep disclosures, survey info, HOA details, and utility notes.
Pre-inspection (optional) if property risk is high.
Pricing plan: first 7 days is your window to win attention.
Coordinate access and documentation with title/HOA.
Keep a backup-offer posture if concessions escalate.

market_practicalities: Foundation movement risk in many Texas regions (soil variability).
Hail/wind exposure in some areas; roof age matters.
High property tax variability by county and exemptions (homestead).
Insurance cost swings (wind/hail, rebuild cost changes).
HOA restrictions can be strict; review bylaws and resale certs early.
property_condition_red_flags: Roof near end-of-life or active leaks
Old/undersized electrical panels or unsafe wiring
agent_questions: HOA rules, dues, transfer fees, leasing restrictions?

property_taxes.high_level: Texas property taxes can be a major payment driver; rates vary widely by county, city, school district, and exemptions.
agent_moves: Verify current tax amount and exemptions status (homestead, etc.).
If buyer is relocating, explain escrow/tax increases as a budgeting risk.
Encourage buyer to confirm projected tax with lender/CPA when needed.

insurance.high_level: Homeowners insurance can vary significantly due to wind/hail exposure, rebuild cost inflation, and claim history.
agent_moves: Encourage buyer to quote insurance early (during option if possible).
If property is older: flag plumbing/electrical/roof as premium drivers.

closing_costs.high_level: Closing costs vary by lender, points, title fees, and local rules; seller concessions may offset buyer cash-to-close depending on terms.

offer_strength_levers: Shorter option period (if buyer is confident)
Stronger earnest money + timely delivery proof
Appraisal gap language (only if buyer can truly cover it)

prioritize: Plumbing leaks / sewer scope if indicated

option_period_explainer_to_buyer.text: BLUF: In Texas, the option period is your due diligence window — inspections, HOA review, and decision-making happen here. We’ll schedule inspections immediately, prioritize big-ticket and safety items, and if something is a deal-breaker we act before the option ends.

earnest_money_instruction_to_buyer.text: Quick heads-up: Earnest money has a delivery deadline in the contract. Let’s get it to the title company early and keep the receipt in the file so there’s zero risk on timing.

inspection_repair_request_to_listing_age.text: We’re not trying to nickel-and-dime. We’re focusing on health/safety and big-ticket items that affect financing and long-term risk. If we can resolve these, we can keep the deal clean and on schedule. Would your seller prefer repairs by licensed pros with receipts, or a credit at closing?

seller_price_reality_check.text: Here’s the honest read: the market tells us the truth in the first 7 days. If we’re priced right, we’ll see real traffic and serious offers. If not, we adjust fast — we don’t wait until the listing goes stale.

appraisal_issue_to_listing_agent.text: If appraisal comes in low, I’d love to solve it without drama. We can look at a price adjustment, a credit, or a structured gap plan — what’s most workable for your seller while keeping the close on track?

fair_housing_guardrails: Use objective property and transaction criteria — avoid people-based language.
Avoid steering: do not describe neighborhoods as 'good for families' or similar.
If asked about demographic topics, redirect to objective data sources and let client decide.
legal_safety: Use your broker/attorney for legal interpretation of forms and disputes.
Keep communications factual, dated, and documented.

recommended_responses: Ask for the minimum missing inputs (city/county, property type, financing, option days)
Provide 3 next moves + a ready-to-send script
